R: @lukecwik

I see what you mean about what you are trying to accomplish. So it doesn't make sense for `ApexRunner` to depend on specific versions of `com.datatorrent:netlet`, `commons-io`, or `hadoop-common`.

But the runner itself, just by linking to particular classes and methods, should at least have a version _range_ for these dependencies that includes those APIs actually referenced. The transitive dependency should presumably fall within that range, but it should work with all compatible transitive deps. Is this not the case?

I don't think we should have compile-time references to classes and methods without declared dependencies except in very special circumstances.
Updated according to the last comment.

Many thanks for your review @davorbonaci, @peihe 

Sorry for not considering that this fix may work only for the local file system.

As @peihe pointed out, when `IOChannelFactory.remove()` can support recursively delete, the workaround `IOChannelFactory.resolve(tempDir, "*")` can be bypassed, which calls `java.nio.file.Path.resolve(tempDir, "*")` and throws Exception on Windows, so this workaround workaround fix can also be bypassed.

And a little advice,  maybe we should avoid the usage that may lead to incompatibility across different systems like "*" as a file path wildcard in the SDK code.

I have read https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-1041, great and detailed issue description and I am very happy to help address it.

By the way, I have found this https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-59 and https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-951.
And BEAM-1041 can be a subtask of BEAM-951 and a sub-subtask of BEAM-59, is that right?

 `IOChannelFactory` now has implementation `FileIOChannelFactory` for local files, and `GcsIOChannelFactory` for Google Cloud Storage, is HDFS and S3 implementation on the way? and Is `HDFSFileSink` going to use `HdfsIOChannelFactory` if there is one in the future (I found now it directly uses HDFS File APIs)?

@peihe Could you please explain these questions?  Thanks a lot:)
There may be wrong understanding and sorry for that.
LGTM

From what I understand, there is no way to express what I'm looking for with the version ranges:

https://maven.apache.org/pom.html#Dependency_Version_Requirement_Specification

I want to say  "use the transitive dependency at the version it was defined at". I found the ignoredUsedUndeclaredDependency tags providing exactly that. Each tag is the equivalent of a white listed transitive dependency. If it wasn't done that way, the changes in the snapshot dependencies would have gone unnoticed and there would potentially be a runtime conflict.

Would you be OK pulling in this change to unblock others (BEAM-1043) while we further discuss alternative solutions?
OK, LGTM to unblock precommit issues.
LGTM. Thank you.
Jenkins failure was unrelated breakage at head fixed by #1418. Please review as green! Rebasing past the fix so it will green up.

r: @bjchambers, @charlesccychen 

Here is the first sketch of the Metrics API for Python. Let me know what you think. All comments are very welcome, and I'll incorporate all your suggestions as best I can.

Things that need special review:
* `MetricName`, `MetricKey`, `MetricResult` are simple `namedtuple`s without any validation. Should we leave them be this way?
*  `MetricsEnvironment` is used as a 'global' object that keeps global state. Its methods are a bit python-awkward (e.g. `set_metrics_supported`, `set_current_container`, `unset_current_container`). Should we rename/refactor them? The `@property` decorator doesn't work for class methods.
* `MetricsContainer` has the `get_Counter`, and `get_Distribution` methods. Should we rename them to `counter` and `distribution`?
* `MetricsAggregation` seemed a bit unnatural in `DirectMetrics`, so I moved it to the `cells.py` file. Should we also separate them in Java? (or should I move them to `DirectMetrics` in Python?)
* The class `MetricUpdate` does not exist. Instead, a metric update is of the basic data value of the metrics (e.g. `DistributionData`, or `int`). Does this seem fine?
* Is the documentation good enough? : )

I'll add more unit tests next week, to be sure that the code is safe and sound.

@tenghuanhe

I marked BEAM-1041 as a sub-task of BEAM-59.

Thanks for bringing up the Windows OS compatibility issues. I created a jira to track it. Comment on it, if you have suggestions:
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-1045

For HDFS and S3 implementation of IOChannelFactory:
I am re-designing it, and design docs are sent to dev@beam.incubator.apache.org. (You can join that mailing list to get involved in Beam's technical discussions.)
I am pasting them in here:

Part 1: IOChannelFactory Redesign: 
https://docs.google.com/document/d/11TdPyZ9_zmjokhNWM3Id-XJsVG3qel2lhdKTknmZ_7M/edit#
Part 2: Configurable BeamFileSystem:
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1-7vo9nLRsEEzDGnb562PuL4q9mUiq_ZVpCAiyyJw8p8/edit#heading=h.p3gc3colc2cs

Also, quick description of the files:
* `base.py` - Contains basic types and classes. `MetricName`, `MetricKey`, `MetricResult`, `MetricUpdates`, `Metric`, `Counter`, `Distribution`.
* `metric.py` - Contains user-facing types and classes. `Metrics`, `MetricsFilter`, `MetricsResults`.
* `internal.py` - Contains internal classes `MetricsEnvironment` and `MetricsContainer`.
* `cells.py` - Contains the thread-safe classes to keep the metric data, and combine it `MetricCell`, `CounterCell`, `DistributionCell`, `MetricAggregation` (and subclasses), and `DistributionData`.
* `direct_metrics.py` - Contains the implementation of `DirectMetrics` and `DirectMetric` classes. : )

Thank you LGTM. (Test failures are unrelated and python tests are ok).

Ok sorry for the checkstyle issue, I just fixed it, I also changed the options to be aligned with what you said, the TranslationModeDetector only detects the mode and does not do any extra logic (I suppose this is better if someday we eventually reuse this function between runners).
I have a test failure on the PR. Let me try a new full build.

Actually If I remove this, some of the tests will fail because the way we detect using Read.Unbounded does not match unbounded PCollections created by transforms e.g. CreateStream.fromQueue.
So there are two options:
1. I change back the visitor code to check every input for unboundness (my previous version, notice that the code is not as nice but it will cover even the future SDF case).
2. I switch the respective tests to force streaming when needed and let the visitor detect only Unbounded.Read transforms.

@kennknowles  First of all, thanks for taking a look during your holidays . 
For the tests,
1. I was under the **wrong** impression that three-way merge hadn't been supported in Gearpump and rejected multiple side inputs (embarrassing...)
2. `PAssertTest#testContainsInAnyOrderFalse` and `PAssertTest#testEmptyFalse` don't pass because of `assertion should have failed`. I haven't figured out why.
3. I lazily copied `RawUnionValue` to gearpump-runner. It's also used in flink-runner so it could be valuable to move `RawUnionValule` to `values`.
Ok, added last remarks, I hope it is ok now.
LGTM pending tests.

Do the gearpump local tests take too long for Jenkins? One thing that helped a lot for Apex was to have them running in precommit while things were under development. You could also add them to precommit or to Travis in one commit just for the PR and then I can remove before the merge. Obviously it cannot be on all the time, but right now sharing the failure stack traces, etc, would be a good way to collaborate.
